Introduction
The safe administration of medicines is the responsibility of every member of staff and healthcare professional involved in the preparation and administration of medicines.

This policy incorporates best practice in line with national guidance. It aligns to the principles within the Royal Pharmaceutical Society & Royal College of Nursing Professional Guidance on the Administration of Medicines in Healthcare Settings (RPS/RCN, 2019).

This is a general policy for all staff involved in the administering of medicines. Specific requirements of speciality clinical areas, and specialist drugs, may not be covered in this document and these may necessitate more detailed local procedures, under the responsibility of that clinical specialty/division.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Define mandatory requirements of the Trust with respect to the preparation and administration of medicines;
Provide standards of practice to be followed by all staff involved;
Signpost to resources for safe medicines administration practice;
Support the learning from medication incidents by providing a framework designed to avoid or eliminate errors;
Ensure staff work within legal and regulatory frameworks.

This policy covers the generic process of preparing medicines into a form suitable to be administered (see exclusions below), where this is undertaken within the clinical area by authorised staff, as well as the actual process of administering to the patient.
This policy applies to all employees of the Trust, including bank staff, and agency staff working in the Trust.
This policy does not cover the following which are detailed in separate policies (see page 2 for details):
Verbal Prescribing Orders/Instructions;
Self-Administration of Medicines by patients;
Parent-administration of Medicines in paediatrics;
Chemotherapy /Chemotherapeutic administration;
IntraVENOUS medicines administration;
IntraTHECAL medicines administration;
Acute Pain analgesia and specialist devices (PCA/ epidural etc.);
Continuous Subcutaneous syringe Pumps (i.e. as used in palliative care).
