data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
MSE Patient Safety & Quality Group
Receiving exception reports and taking action in response to issues raised from Medicines Assurance Group and/or department of pharmacy.
MSE Medicines Assurance Group (MAG)
Ensuring the effective implementation, use and timely review of this policy;
Ensuring that monitoring arrangements are appropriately performed by the site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Groups (MOSG);
Where necessary, escalating concerns to the Chief Nursing Officer & site Director/s of Nursing or Chief Medical Officer & site Medical Directors as appropriate;
Exception reporting to Patient Safety & Quality Group on developments, concerns and progress concerning preparation & administration of medicines.
Site Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group (MOSG)
Monitoring this policy through incident reports;
Escalating issues to site divisional governance groups and MAG as appropriate.
Divisional & Speciality Governance Groups
Monitoring this policy through incident reports;
Ensure issues identified through audit are actioned promptly;
Support MOSG and MAG in the promotion and enforcement of risk reduction strategies associated with the administration of medicines.
Chief Executive

As the Trust's accountable officer has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete and up to date documents in place to govern and guide activities so that legal and national requirements are met.
Chief Nursing Officer
Ensuring that there is safe and effective implementation of this policy and maintained compliance in all areas of the organisation;
Ensuring there are the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) available for all staff they oversee;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy;
Ensuring deviations from this policy are fully risk assessed and they take accountability for these deviations within the organisation;
Ensuring any escalated administration of medicines issues involving professions and staff they oversee are appropriately managed corporately;
Ensures medication errors are reported and investigated in a complete and timely
manner.
Site Director of Nursing / Deputy Directors of Nursing / Director of Midwifery
Ensuring that there is safe and effective implementation of this policy and maintained compliance in all areas they are responsible for;
Ensuring there are the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) available for all staff they oversee;
Ensuring sufficient resources are in place to implement this policy;
Ensuring any escalated administration of medicines issues involving professions and staff they oversee are appropriately managed corporately;
Ensures medication errors are reported and investigated in a complete and timely
manner.
Chief Medical Officer & site Medical Directors
Ensuring that there is safe and effective implementation of this policy and maintained compliance in all areas of the organisation/site;
Ensuring any escalated administration of medicines issues involving professions they oversee are appropriately managed corporately.
The Chief Medical Officer and site Medical Directors delegate this responsibility to the Divisional Clinical Directors and specialty Clinical Leads for delivery.
Chief Pharmacist
Setting the overall framework and policy standards for safe preparation and administration of medicines across the organisation, in line with regulatory and best practice guidance;
Ensuring a monitoring process exists and functions for policy standard.
The Chief Pharmacist delegates day-to-day implementation responsibilities to the Deputy Chief Pharmacist, and site pharmacy Heads of Department for delivery.
Associate Directors of Nursing / Head(s) of Midwifery / Therapies Director (or other divisional equivalents)
Ensuring local dissemination of this policy within their service/s;
Implementing and maintaining safe systems and practices within their divisions under the direction of the Chief Nurse/Directors of Nursing and pharmacy;
Ensuring monitoring and audit activities are undertaken regularly and robustly;
Providing the opportunity for delivery of relevant education and training for staff they oversee;
Ensures medication errors are reported and investigated in a complete and timely manner.
Matron
Ensuring that implementation and maintenance of safe systems and practices has happened effectively in areas they oversee;

Ensuring that all medicine administration errors are appropriately reported, investigated and lessons learnt in a complete and timely manner. This is completed in accordance with Trust policies for incident management (MSEPO- 19014 & 19015), and medication errors MSEPO-20206;
Actively engaging with the medication safety team and Medicines Optimisation and Safety Group for shared learning and quality improvement.
Ward Manager (Nurse/Midwife-in-charge of a clinical area), or other department equivalents
Ensuring that implementation and maintenance of safe systems and practices has happened effectively on ward/department;
Ensuring safe preparation, administration and monitoring of medicines in their clinical area, including that full second checking is happening, in accordance with this document;
Ensuring staff receive the minimum training, supervision and support in achieving and maintaining competence in medicines administration;
Ensuring only staff with appropriate competencies are carrying out those tasks with respect to medicines preparation and administration; including second checks of those tasks;
Determining, and communicating to their team, the level of supervision required for bank or agency staff on shift, with respect to the administration of medicines;

Ensuring that essential equipment/sundries are regularly ordered and are readily available at all times. Specifically this must include insulin syringes, insulin safety needles and oral syringes in a range of sizes as appropriate for clinical area;

Ensuring information sources for medicines administration used by their team are always complete, up-to-date and approved by pharmacy. They must ensure only approved medication reference sources and information are on display/ available to their staff;

Ensuring that all medicine administration errors are appropriately reported, investigated and lessons learnt in a complete and timely manner. This is completed in accordance with Trust policies for incident management (MSEPO- 19014 & 19015), and medication errors MSEPO-20206.

Administering Person (i.e. Registered Nurse, Midwife, ODP, Doctor, Pharmacist, Pharmacy Technician, Allied Health Professional or other Trust- competency trained staff that administers medicines (e.g. Renographer))
Works within current legislation, Trust policies and procedures, within the code of conduct for their professional body, and/or any other expected standards of practice for job role;

Ensuring that they have the relevant competencies in the safe use and observation of all medical equipment/devices they need to use; and ensure that they only work within their personal signed-off competency;
Ensuring they correctly prepare, administer and monitor medicines given in line with this document;
Ensuring that they do not prepare, second check and/or administer any medicine where they do not hold the specific valid Trust competency for that medicine type (i.e. IV medication);
Undertaking relevant training;

Ensuring the timely and efficient administration of medicines and full documentation of all administered /non-administered medicines on the drug chart (including extra details in patient health record / ePMA as required);
Ensuring actions are taken promptly when medicines are omitted;
Obtaining medicines promptly (and always critical medicines) where they are not immediately available on the ward/department;
Ordering medicines in the correct way from pharmacy;
Ensuring they are familiar with the usual dosing, frequency and administration method of the medicine they are giving and any monitoring required;
Ensures they understand the action of the drug administered, their compatibility side effects, monitoring required and know what action to take as appropriate;
Ensuring they only use up-to-date, authorised and valid reference sources when checking how to prepare and/or administer a medicine;
Weighing patients and documenting their weight in kg on the drug chart;
Adhering to Evidence based Practice in Infection Control Guidelines;
Ensuring they obtain and carryout second independent checks for preparation and/or administration of medicines, where required to do so, as per this policy and all other medication policies.
Providing medication counselling to patients, including dosing, frequency, side effects to be aware of and how to use (i.e. inhaler devices), in line with their competency;
Proactively assisting in ensuring sufficient stock of essential safety items required for administration (i.e. insulin syringes, needles and oral syringes);
Actively encouraging the bringing into hospital of patients-own medicines;
Ensuring correct security, storage, and removal of medicines using the patient's bedside medicines locker (inpatient wards);
Ensuring all medicines the patient continues to require are moved with the patient on transfer or discharge from their clinical area;
Ensuring correct disposal of medicine, depending on type;
Ensuring timely and open reporting of medication errors and near misses, including active engagement in learning from incidents in line with Trust policy for medication errors MSEPO-20206.
4.13.1 Administering registered Staff (in addition to 4.13 above):

Providing direct supervision of students undertaking medicines preparation and administration. The registrant will personally sign the drug chart after administration, as the authorised administering person;
Observing carers in the carer administration of medicines, where applicable;
Ensuring self-administration is offered and facilitated, where appropriate.
4.13.2 Administering person accountability:

Within the Renal Department (including all inpatient dialysis beds), the registered nurse is wholly accountable for all activities related to drug preparation undertaken by unregistered department staff in their presence.

Within the Catheter Laboratory (Diagnostic Imaging Department), the registered clinical scientist will be wholly accountable for all activities related to drug preparation undertaken by unregistered department staff in their presence.
Registered and student Midwives (in addition to above)
Ensuring their awareness of and understanding of all practices they undertake involving midwives' exemptions;
Having the relevant work competences for midwives exemptions;
Ensuring they check the exemption list regularly.
Student Nurse, Student Midwife or Student ODP
Working within current legislation, within the code of conduct for their professional body, and/or any other expected standards of practice for job role;
Ensuring they only prepare and/or administer medicines whilst under the direct supervision of their registered nurse/midwife/ODP;
Ensuring that they do not act as the second check for one other registrant preparing and/or administering medicines.
Registered Pharmacy Staff (i.e. Pharmacist or Pharmacy Technician)
Ensuring they are familiar with the usual dosing and administration method of the medicines they advise upon, within their specific professional competency;
Ensuring they understand the action of the drug administered, their compatibility and side effects where appropriate, within their specific professional competency;
Supporting other healthcare professionals in the provision of clear, accurate and unambiguous advice on administering medicines;
Ensuring they only use up-to-date, authorised and valid reference sources when providing advice on how to prepare and/or administer a medicine;
Ensuring timely and open reporting of medication errors and near misses, including active engagement in learning from incidents in line with Trust policy for
medication errors MSEPO-20206.
Authority to prepare and administer

This is a general policy and may be superseded by area specific authorised documents. Where no such documents exist, this policy must be followed. Detailed procedures may exist in clinical areas, which define grades of staff who may administer medicines, the circumstances under which they are authorised to do so and whether or not any check by a second person is required for all or part of the administration process.

Registered healthcare professionals who administer medicines, or when appropriate delegate the administration of medicines, are accountable for their actions, non- actions and omissions, and exercise professionalism and professional judgement at all times (RPS/RCN 2019).
They must adhere to all relevant professional and regulatory standards and guidance (RPS/RCN, 2019), and local Trust policies and guidelines.

Medicines may only be prepared and/or administered to patients by authorised staff within the Trust who are appropriately trained and assessed as competent to do so (RPS/RCN 2019). All qualifications and competencies must be up-to-date. This will include:
Demonstrated competence in medicines administration and calculations;
Newly registered staff having undertaken a period of preceptorship, including assessment prior to administering medication;
Newly appointed staff having undertaken appropriate induction training.
All staff must be employed by the Trust to specifically undertake preparation and/or administration of medicines as part of their documented job role.
Only the following authorised staff may administer medicines:
Registered Nurse (RN1 / RNA/ RNChild) with the NMC;
Registered Midwife (RM) with the NMC;
Registered Medical Practitioner with the GMC;
Registered Operating Department Practitioner with the HCPC (where permitted in their theatre of work);
Registered Allied Health Professional with their UK regulatory body (i.e. HCPC, GPhC etc.), where competent in medicines administration;

Student nurse, student midwife or medical student where there is full direct supervision (accompanied and observed without distraction) by a registered nurse, registered midwife or doctor. For CDs refer to MSEPO-20237;
Student ODP where there is full direct supervision (accompanied and observed without distraction) by a registered ODP or an anaesthetist. For CDs refer to MSEPO-20237;

Non-registered staff where they hold a valid & pharmacy-approved Trust- competency for the specific medicines involved and this is authorised by both the senior nurse manager for a clinical area and the Chief Pharmacist.
Staff who are authorised to prescribe are also authorised to administer the same range of medicines, within their competency.
Only specifically trained and competent staff may administer medication by the intra-arterial, epidural or other specialist routes.
Only specifically trained and competent staff may administer cytotoxic chemotherapy, intended for the treatment of malignant disease, by any route.
Physiotherapists, Speech and Language Therapists (SLT) and Chiropodists

5.10.1 Physiotherapists and SLTs may only administer medicines to patients when authorised by both a doctor and their manager, and when they personally are prepared to accept the accountability. They must demonstrate competency which is documented and signed off by their manager. There must be a written agreement to allow medication to be administered under a PGD.
5.10.2 State registered chiropodists with a certificate of competence may administer those medicines defined in the legislation, and any pharmacy medicine they consider appropriate for their work.

Authorised staff must only administer medicines and/or supply them against a valid and legal authorisation by a registered prescriber (medical or non-medical prescriber) or other legal means as specified below:
Prescription written by an authorised prescriber - see Prescribing of Medicines Policy;
Patient Specific Direction (PSD) by a doctor (e.g. entry into medical notes during an outpatient clinic);
Trust Patient Group Direction (PGD) - see MSEPO-20210 Development Approval and Implementation of PGDs Policy;
A specific discretionary medicine in defined circumstances – see MSEPO-20211 Discretionary medicines administration policy;
Trust adopted national written instruction (see below);
Verbal order (in exceptional circumstances only – see MSEPO-21085 Verbal Prescribing Orders Policy;
A specific medicine as detailed within Midwives Exemptions legislation to be administered by a registered midwife only (see section 7);
A nuclear medicine referral authorised in accordance with an ARSAC certificate holder's guidelines (see section 30).
Written instructions

5.12.1  Under the national written instruction that has been adopted by the Trust, authorised Trust competency-assessed staff may administer the seasonal influenza vaccine to the organisations staff, including peer to peer vaccination. This is published alongside PGDs on the staff intranet.
Self-Administration by patients
5.13.1  Patients may administer their own medicines only in accordance with the Trust Self- Administration of Medicines Policy (or equivalent).
Carer Administration of medicines within the Trust

5.14.1 In some cases carers may administer prescribed medication to their patient/relative, but the registered nurse/midwife must take overall responsibility for ensuring the medication has been given correctly and safely. The nurse-in-charge (or equivalent) must approve this and it will be documented in the patient health record. In doing so, any administration by a carer should be observed by the nurse/midwife caring for the patient in order to ensure patient safety is not compromised in anyway.

5.14.2 Where there is suspicion of a safeguarding issue then this must be escalated in accordance with the MSEPO-20235 Adult Safeguarding Policy or MSEPO-19010 Child Safeguarding Policy. Carer administration must not happen if there is any suspicion.
5.14.3 In adults, assess the carer in accordance with the Trust Self-administration of Medicines Policy (or equivalent).
5.14.4 In paediatrics please refer to the Parent Administration of Medication Policy (or equivalent).

5.14.5 Drugs given by the nebuliser route must be set up and the nebuliser treatment commenced by the registered nurse. Carers must not be allowed to switch on medical gases for nebuliser treatment. When the nebulised medicine has been given the registered nurse is responsible for turning the medical gas and associated equipment off.

5.14.6 In ALL instances medication must be locked away in accordance with MSEPO- 20205 Policy for Safe and Secure Storage of Medicines. Nurses should open the bedside medicine locker for the carer at the time of administration but not leave it unattended.
Second independent checks (second-checking)
An authorised administering person may administer medicines on their own and is fully responsible for their actions in most circumstances, except as outlined below.
A second person must be involved if the following is being administered;
controlled drugs (see MSEPO-20237 CD Policy);
intravenous drugs (see Intravenous medicines policy);
injectable cytotoxic drugs for anti-cancer treatment;

where complex calculation of the dose is required (this refers to the use of age, body weight etc. to define a dose. It does not refer to a situation when it is simply a matter of giving multiple dose units);
to a person under the age of sixteen (16) years, except as detailed within a PGD, for any injectable route;
any specific clinical area where designated appropriate by the clinical area nurse/midwife manager and Principal Pharmacist with divisional responsibility.

Where a clinical area designates requirements for additional second independent checks, these must be documented in the local specialty procedures and protocols and must be explicitly covered at staff induction.
Any administering person can at any time, for any medicine, seek assistance to have a second person involved.
Both staff are accountable and responsible for the preparation and administration of medication to the specific patient.
What is a second independent check?
6.6.1 A second independent check is both witnessing the preparation of the medicine and the subsequent administration to the correct patient.

6.6.2 A second-independent check means that a checking process is undertaken by an authorised second person who checks all elements of the entire process separate from the self-check the first administering person has done. The second person must never be guided by the first person, as this may result in errors not being identified and corrected. For example working through a calculation together is not an acceptable second-check because it is not independent.

6.6.3 The second person must be able to see every part of the process and all materials involved in the preparation of the medicine (prescriptions, vials/bags, information resources they access themselves etc.) and administration (rate setting on pumps, wristband checks etc.).
6.6.4 The second person will personally (this list is not exhaustive):
Check the prescription;
Check information resources for guidance on how to prepare and administer;
Check materials used to prepare the medicine are correct and appropriate;
Undertake calculations on their own to determine correct dose;
Watch the assembly of the medicine into a suitable form to be administered;
Watch completion of any drug additive labels adhered to the prepared medicine and only add their signature after checking all aspects;
Attend patient bedside with the first person, checking all patients details against prescription in line with this policy;
Witnessing the infusion pump set up (where needed) and check entry of the correct rate;
Complete all requirements under MSEPO-20237 CD Policy, where required.
Documenting second independent checks
6.7.1 Second check signatures on the drug chart/ ePMA system must only happen after the medicine has been administered. This must be done immediately after administration, without delay.

6.7.2 On a paper chart, the administration box will be endorsed with two signatures (as initials). The administering person's initials shall appear at the top of the administration box, with the second checker person's initials at the bottom.
6.7.3 On ePMA systems, the second checker is recorded in the ‘witness' box.
Authorised second persons to check preparation and administration are:
Registered Nurse (RN1 / RNA/RNChild) with the NMC;
Registered Midwife (RM) with the NMC;
Registered Medical Practitioner with the GMC;
Registered Operating Department Practitioner with the HCPC (where permitted in their theatre of work);
Registered Allied Health Professional with their UK regulatory body (i.e. HCPC, GPhC etc.), where competent in medicines administration;

Non-registered staff where they hold a valid & pharmacy-approved Trust- competency for the specific medicines involved and this is authorised by both the senior nurse manager for a clinical area and the Chief Pharmacist.

A registered nurse, ODP or doctor may draw up an injection for administration by another doctor provided that the administering doctor has sight of the original container and is satisfied as to the nature and quantity of the drug to be administered, in line with this policy.
For second checking in Nuclear medicine, Renal unit, Diagnostic imaging and Theatres please refer to specific sections 28-31 within this policy.
Second checker restrictions: Nursing and Midwifery Students
6.11.1 Second-checking may only be performed for adult patient oral medication only. (i.e. injectable medicines can only be given once registered as a nurse/midwife).
6.11.2 A nursing student in a clinical placement may act as witness where appropriate under the supervision of a registered nurse. The registered nurse must first

ascertain that the student has received theoretical teaching in the administration of medicines from the University education provider. This can be verified by checking the student's Clinical Nursing Skills Record with the University education provider.
6.11.3 The supervising registered nurse remains accountable for the administration.
Neonatal departments
6.12.1  Second person checks for all neonatal medicines must be a registered nurse. All medicines must be checked, administered and signed for by two registered nurses or midwives.
Paediatric departments

6.13.1  Single-registered nurse checks are permitted for all oral, buccal, sublingual, topical, inhalers, nebulisers and mouthwash medicines administered (except CDs). Second person checks are required for all other medicines and these must be checked, administered and signed for by two registered nurses.
Healthcare Assistants (HCA) / Nursery Nurses
6.14.1  Healthcare Assistants and Nursery Nurses may not participate in the second checking of medicines.
Bank Registered Nurses/Midwives

6.15.1  Bank Registered staff should undertake the same level of training and have the same skills and competencies as permanent registered staff. However it remains the responsibility of the nurse/midwife-in-charge of an area to decide if it is necessary that they should be accompanied for additional second-checking purposes when administering medicines to a patient.
Agency Registered Nurses/Midwives

6.16.1  It is the responsibility of the nurse-in-charge of an area to decide if it is necessary that they should be accompanied for additional second-checking purposes when administering medicines to a patient. Checks must be made to ensure they are qualified & authorised to administer certain medicines at this Trust (i.e. injectables and specifically intravenous medicines).
Midwife exemptions
Under Schedule 17 of The Human Medicines Regulations 2012, there are exemptions from the general rules for Prescription-only medicines and Pharmacy medicines.

A PGD is not necessary for midwives to be able to supply and/or administer any of those substances that are specified in medicines legislation under the 'midwives exemptions'. Midwives should refer directly to the legislation and the ‘Practising as a midwife in the UK' document published by the NMC.
All midwives must be aware of, understand and have the relevant work competences for all practices they undertake involving midwives' exemptions. This also applies to student midwives.
Midwives are responsible for ensuring they check this exemption list regularly to ensure they remain working legally with respect to medicines administration.

Please refer to the department of Midwifery for guidance. Additional departmental procedures and guidelines may be issued by the Trust department of Midwifery. All midwifery staff must adhere to these documents and standards detailed within.
Where an exemption is used, it will be documented clearly in the patient record and designated drug chart, where available, in accordance with Midwifery departmental procedures.
As a minimum this entry will contain:
Time and date of transaction / administration;
Drug, strength and form;
Route;
Quantity (and exact directions on label if making a supply);
Whether supplied, sold or administered;
Midwife identifier/s (printed name and signature).
Valid Trust prescription stationary for administering medicines

Prescriptions must only be written on official Trust prescription chart/s. This may be the site paper drug chart or on a valid Trust electronic prescribing and medicines administration system (i.e. WellSky ePMA / Metavision ePMA / ChemoCare ePMA).
In outpatient/day-case/theatre settings this may be on designated pre-printed or electronic prescriptions or be entered in the patient health record, as per local procedure.

It is never acceptable to administer from a drug chart of another healthcare provider, or any chart from a nursing/care home. This also applies to drugs brought into hospital by a patient and drugs administered by registered nurses in the patient's own home. All medicines need to be reviewed and re-written onto Trust Drug charts / ePMA.

All paper drug charts must be used only for the maximum period for which designed, and must be rewritten after two consecutive weeks. Any administration of medication beyond the pre-printed administration grid for the drug technically constitutes illegal administration as the prescription is no longer valid.
The cancellation of medication is the responsibility of the authorised prescriber, and should be signed and dated at the time of the decision. For paper charts this will be

designated by a clear line down the administration grid and then diagonally across the remaining section of the grid. In WellSky ePMA the prescription is displayed as suspended or discontinued, and cannot be administered against.

If multiple paper Drug Charts are in use, these should be numbered 1 of 2 etc. and the prescription charts held together by means of a treasury tag or filed together in a ring binder folder. Supplementary paper drug charts (e.g. syringe pump) must be clearly indicated on the front of the main paper drug chart and be affixed to/filed with the main drug chart to prevent doses being missed.
Preparing medicines: general requirements
Wherever possible, medicines will be supplied by the pharmacy department in a form suitable for direct administration to the patient.

When medicines have to be measured, mixed or reconstituted etc. in a clinical area, prior to administration, this shall be undertaken in a designated clean area that is approved for the purpose by the appropriate clinical area manager and site pharmacy medication safety team.

Suitable equipment, devices and other sundries which aid the administration of medicines must be available and present at all times (appropriate to medicines administered in that clinical area) (RPS/RCN, 2019). This includes sufficient quantity and variety of the correct needles, syringes and giving sets. Refer also to MSEPO-20205 Policy for Safe and Secure Storage of Medicines. This includes (but is not exhaustive of):
Subcutaneous insulin safety needles (for nurse administration);
Subcutaneous insulin needles (for patient self-administration);
Insulin unit-graduated syringes (i.e. U50 / U100);
Oral syringes and enteral giving sets (see section 18).

Sufficient space to allow safe working is required, especially for the safe preparation of injectable medicines. Work surfaces should be easily cleaned and not cluttered. For all Trust inpatient wards this should be at least two metres of such worktop required for medicine preparation as per HBN 14-02 (NHSE, 2021). See also MSEPO-20205 Policy for Safe and Secure Storage of Medicines.

Good lighting levels should be provided to medicines storage and worktop planes (see CIBSE's (2019) LG02/19 ‘Lighting guide'). Appropriate switching should be provided to allow this to be operated together or as stand-alone (if required), for example at night; as per HBN 14-02 (NHSE, 2021).
Administering medicines: general principles
The administering person must have an overall understanding of the medicine being administered (RPS/RCN, 2019).

The entire drug chart must be reviewed by the administering person, not just the medicines due at a particular drug round/ time. This ensures a full check of medicines to be undertaken, pre-planning for upcoming doses due (i.e. ordering in advance) etc.

If an administering person has any doubt about the medicine they are administering, they should request a second independent check from another authorised person. If doubt about the medication or its administration persists then the prescriber must be contacted, or a pharmacy professional.
Whilst it is acceptable to use calculators to identify quantities of medicine, they must not be a substitute for arithmetical skills.

Where drug trolleys are used, they must be locked or immobilised when unattended. It is acknowledged that during a drug round, the trolley may have to be left in order to administer medicines to a patient. However, if this requires the nurse to leave the trolley for any length of time or spend some time behind privacy curtains, the trolley must be closed and locked. Refer to MSEPO-20205 Policy for Safe and Secure Storage of Medicines. Failure to securely lock a trolley may be considered a disciplinary offence.
Administering staff are expected to:
be aware of the patient's current care plan;
have considered issues around consent in accordance with regulatory and professional body guidance;
know the therapeutic uses of the medicine to be administered, its normal dosage, side effects, precautions and contraindications;
have considered the dosage, method of administration, route and timing of the administration in the context of the condition of the patient and co-existing therapies;

undertake appropriate and complete checks outlined within this document to ensure the correct identification of the patient, correct methodology of preparation and administration & documentation is followed in order to minimise hazardous risks to patients;

contact the prescriber or another authorised prescriber, without delay, where contra-indications to the prescribed medicine are discovered, where the patient develops a reaction to the medicine, or where assessment of the patient indicates that the medicine is no longer suitable.
Administering staff should consider a patient-centred approach taking account of:
the patients' age;
any choice they have exercised relating to their medicines;
how their lifestyle may influence their compliance with regimens (e.g. timings of administration);
any cultural, religious or other personal beliefs which may affect the patients approach to having their medicines given to them (e.g. fasting, presence of pork products etc.);
any appropriate allergies, intolerances and previous adverse drug reactions;
any existing medical conditions and prescriptions the patient has and the opportunity for any interaction between medicines and disease;
any previously occurred or potential adverse drug reactions.

Any concerns or queries identified should be discussed with the prescriber caring for the patient. Pharmacists and Pharmacy Technicians should also be involved, where needed, who may be able to support medicines adherence.
Distractions / interruptions

10.9.1  It is recognised within the busy clinical setting that administering persons may be interrupted whilst undertaking medicines administration. Attempts should be made to avoid distractions (see also section 10.10). Where the interruption is unavoidable the administering person must re-start their administration checks again, rather than try to re-start the process from where they left off. This ensures that important steps in the checking process are not accidentally missed.
Red apron scheme
In some parts of the Trust a ‘red apron scheme' is in operation. Where operating this scheme it must be adhered to in full.

Registered nurses administering medication on a scheduled medication round wear a red apron/tabard that clearly states ‘do not disturb'. This is to reduce the number of interruptions that a nurse administering medication may experience, therefore reducing the likelihood of error.
Nursing staff performing a drug round may attend to patient needs outside of the scope of a drug round if he/she feels that this will not distract from a crucial calculation or preparation of drug.
The red apron does not exclude the staff member from attending emergency situations as required.
Wards should display appropriate media that informs patients and relatives on the purpose of this safety initiative.
Information and advice for preparation and administration
Where information sources are referred to in order to prepare and/or administer a medicine they must be up-to-date, and from approved sources.
Never use out of date reference sources or one where its origin cannot be verified. Pharmacy will validate medication resources for use in the Trust.

Online resources available on the intranet include links to Medusa Injectable Medicines Guide and Online BNF and BNF for Children. Online resources should not be printed and stored in clinical areas because they can become out of date. Always access online each time information is required.
The online BNF (smartphone app or desktop version) are the preferred BNF platforms. Where a paper copy exists it must be the current edition.

Ward/Department Managers are responsible for ensuring all information that exists in their area, pertaining to medicines use, is authorised by the department of pharmacy and document controlled to ensure it is up-to-date and accurate. This includes all posters and reference books.
Ward/dept. staff should not create their own medicines information resources without validation of the content by pharmacy before publication.
Any materials which are not validated by the department of pharmacy or are out of date may be removed.
Pharmacists are available 24/7 where advice on medicines is not available from other readily available sources.

For more complex queries the Trust Medicines Information Service based at Broomfield pharmacy is available for all staff (all sites) Monday-Friday to carry out a more extensive search and analysis of resources.
Registered pharmacy staff will make signed endorsements on drug charts to support safe preparation and administration. These should be taken as valid directions by administering staff to follow.
Checking the prescription / direction to administer
Check patient identifiers – has the right patient been identified:
Full name of patient (caution for similar looking/sounding names);
Date of birth;
NHS number or hospital number (NHS number MUST be ascertained in paediatrics).
Is an accurate weight documented in kilograms (kg)?

12.2.1 Weight must be documented on the patient drug chart. Administering staff can add this information. Where this is updated on paper charts, add a date beside the updated record. In WellSky ePMA dates are recorded automatically.

12.2.2 Patient weight documentation must be present on grounds of patient safety. Many drugs are dosed by weight (e.g. enoxaparin, gentamicin) and often dosing is weight- based for patients 16 years and under.

12.2.3 If it is not possible to weigh the patient due to the clinical condition, an estimated weight must be present. Where a patient's estimated weight has been used to dose a drug for a patient attempts should be made to ascertain the patient's actual weight as soon as practicable. Any significant differences should be highlighted to the prescriber and drug doses amended if necessary. The documented weight must be annotated as ‘estimated'.
Check the ‘allergy and sensitivity status' box on drug chart/ ePMA

12.3.1 Verify it is complete, documented and signed. If this is not filled in, the allergy status must be confirmed before any medicine is given to the patient (excluding emergency situations or neonates).

12.3.2 Refer to MSBPO-18020 RM Policy for the Management of Allergy Status. Action must be taken by ward/dept. staff to complete allergy status as soon as possible. Any authorised person can update an allergy status.
Is the prescription complete (i.e. safe & legal)?

12.4.1 The following must be checked. Each part must be present, clear and unambiguous. Inappropriate abbreviations must not be accepted and never used (i.e. ‘u' or ‘iu' can (and has been) misinterpreted leading to dangerous overdoses).
Drug name;
Dosage in metric units (mg, micrograms etc.);
Frequency: is time of day entered on paper charts?;
Route
Dated;
Signed by prescriber;
For paper: written in indelible ink or typed, but must still contain a valid date & inked signature;
For ePMA: the generated prescription is indelible by nature, and dates and signatures are auto-generated and will always be present;
12.4.2 If any aspect is missing, illegible or unclear/ambiguous advise the ward doctor (or prescriber for elsewhere) without delay and withhold the medication until the

prescription has been completed. Appropriate action must be taken, particularly with critical medicines (see section 22). It is not acceptable to delay referral to a doctor or non-medical prescriber. The ward pharmacist can be consulted for advice.
Checking the medicine before administration
Before selecting the medicine
13.1.1 Check the medicine has not already been administered against the drug chart. In ePMA systems only doses not signed/accounted for will be available on chart to administer.
13.1.2 Check if any recently changed/ re-written prescriptions: when was the last dose given of this medicine? Is it safe to give the next dose at this time?
13.1.3 Check correct time of administration. Some are specific (i.e. short-acting insulin with mealtimes) or outside of normal drug round times for symptom control (i.e. anti- Parkinson's medicines).

13.1.4 Check appropriateness for ‘when required' (prn) doses. Check the time of the last administration of this drug. It may have been re-written on the chart so check all STAT, regular and prn sections of the chart. Confirm the dose is within the maximum frequency and dose for a 24 hour period.
13.1.5 Check for contra-indications and interactions. If so withhold the dose and inform the appropriate doctor immediately. Document their response in patient health record.

13.1.6 Check for any additional instructions, including safety considerations. The administering person must be satisfied that the dose is appropriate for the patient, including factors such as age, weight and renal function, within their competency.
Check the drug name, formulation, strength & route

13.2.1 Never assume the medicine is in the same shape, colour or container as the last time it was used. The same drugs can vary significantly depending on manufacturer, and within the NHS these can regularly change.

13.2.2 Exercise caution with sound-alike, look-alike drugs (SALADs) and combination drugs (e.g. co- amilofruse / co-amilozide) and inhalers. The entire drug name must be read: beginning, middle and end of the word/s.

13.2.3 Where there is a need to ensure the same formulation/ brand etc. (usually due to bioavailability differences) this will be clearly annotated on the drug chart/ePMA. Brand names will be prescribed where this is the case. If in doubt, refer to the pharmacy team.
13.2.4 Verify that the medicine selected is the most appropriate strength for the dose you administering. Caution for drug strengths in micrograms to ensure they are not confused with mg.

13.2.5 Be aware formulations are different – immediate release compared to sustained release. Medicines with lettering after the drug name such as SR, CR. PR, MR, etc. denote a longer-acting preparation. These are not interchangeable with immediate release preparations.
13.2.6 When checking strengthes of liquids, carefully calculate what amount of medicine this is per millilitre (mL). Strengths of oral liquids can vary.

13.2.7 Check the route of administration (caution with non-bioequivalent preparations see above): Is the route specified on the label? Is the medicine you have selected authorised for giving by the route prescribed?
Check the drug labelling/container against the prescription.

13.3.1 If the dispensing label or container is damaged, altered or illegible/obliterated in any way or the administering person is uncertain of the contents, the medicine must not be used. Contact pharmacy for advice that may lead to a replacement supply issued.
13.3.2 Under no circumstance should a nurse/midwife or other professional make alterations to labelled medicines. The only exceptions are:
addition of a drug additive label to prepared injectable medicine;
to mark the date of opening / expiry date;
to write patient name / identifier on container;
to complete a section of a pre-labelled TTA pack (Refer to Discharge Medication Policy, or equivalent).
13.3.3 Under no circumstances may a medicine labelled for a specific patient be given to another patient.
13.3.4 Administering persons must never remove labels from previously dispensed medicines and return these to ward stock cupboards.
Check the expiry date of the drug (and expiry date once opened, if applicable).
13.4.1 Ensure any special storage requirements have been adhered to, such as refrigeration. Storage instructions will be detailed on the label or manufacturers packaging.
13.4.2 If the administering person has any doubts about the suitability of the medication available to give, they must not administer and should contact pharmacy for further advice.
Preparing and administering a dose to the patient
Preparing the dose
14.1.1 Never prepare doses without verifying all of the above checks are correct.
14.1.2 Calculate the dose if appropriate. For complex calculations (i.e. based on weight or a conversion), check with a second authorised person.

14.1.3 Only draw-up liquid doses using the appropriate syringe. See oral/enteral administration and insulin administration sections below). Once measured always re-check the measured dose in the syringe.
14.1.4 Follow any documented advice from pharmacy staff on the drug chart.
Administering the dose to the patient
14.2.1 Follow the principles of P.A.W.S at the bedside:
Patient is correct;
Allergy status is checked;
Wristband on patient as a double-check;
Signing the drug chart after administration.
14.2.2 Take the measured dose to the patient with the drug chart (paper or ePMA).

14.2.3 Patient: Check the full patient name with the patient against the drug chart. Verbally ask the patient their name where possible. Patients should tell the administering staff their name and not the other way around (in case they may have misheard you).

14.2.4 Allergy Status is checked / confirmed: Look at the allergy & sensitivities section of the drug chart again. Verify (verbally with patient where possible) that they are not allergic to the medicine being administered. Check all medicines if unsure (caution with penicillins).

14.2.5 Wristband check: Use to double-check patient and allergy status against the prescription. Refer to MSEPO-21002 Patient identification policy and procedure. Check the patient's hospital/NHS number on the drug chart against the wristband. This must be done, even if you feel the patient is well known to you.
14.2.6 Administer the dose in line with this document (see sections below for oral liquids, patches etc.) and associated specialist medication policies.
14.2.7 Always remain with the patient until dose has been given/ taken. Never leave medicines at the bedside.
14.2.8 For patient's self-administering refer to Self-Administration of Medicines Policy (or equivalent).

14.2.9 Sign the drug chart: Complete immediately after administration to declare the drug has been administered. This is done by entering staff initials in the designated box on the drug chart against the correct day, medication given and time. In ePMA this is entered electronically by ticking drugs and clicking to confirm (‘charting'). A blank box indicates the drug has not been given and risks accidental double-dosing.
14.2.10 If the patient is receiving a variable dose, record the actual dose given on the drug chart, as a ‘note' in WellSky ePMA and the patient health record.
14.2.11 A community midwife shall record the administration of all drugs in the patient's midwifery record.
Disposal of doses

14.3.1  Medicines prepared for use, or administration, and subsequently not used, or not given in the treatment of the patient concerned, must be disposed of in accordance with the Safe Handling of Medicines Policy and Trust Waste Handling Policies (or equivalent). They must never be returned to the container from which they were taken, or stored in any other container in the clinical area.
Medicines counselling and adherence

Involve the patient (or carer where possible) at the outset when giving medicines to identify any counselling needs, potential compliance problems or difficulties. These can be referred to the medical team and pharmacy to support medicines review. The patient should be involved in any decisions taken.

Counselling should be given before the medication is first given and re-enforced during the admission and at discharge where appropriate. This prepares the patient for self-administration at home to encourage adherence to medication regimens.

For all new medicines the administering nurse (or equivalent) is responsible for and should ensure that the patient (or carer) understands their treatment. They should reinforce this throughout their interaction with the patient.
Counselling should include:
What the drug is for (its purpose);
Any possible side effects they may experience and what to do if the patient experiences them. As a guide the most common side effects are listed first against each drug in the online BNF;
How to use their medicine – including demonstration of how to use inhalers, injections (i.e. insulin/ enoxaparin), eye/nose/ear drops etc.;
What dose to take, time, and how best to do this (e.g. after food, full glass or water etc.);
Any special storage arrangements (e.g. store in fridge).

Where counselling the patient is not possible, the person who will be supporting the patient with medicines administration post-discharge should be provided equivalent counselling advice (i.e. relative, informed carers etc.).

Pharmacy can advise on the optimisation of medication regimens, and some medication aids are available from pharmacy on request. Please refer to the MSEPO-21084 Appropriate Use of Medication Compliance Aids Policy.
Patient's own drugs (POD's)
Patient's own medicines remain the property of the patient at all times.
Never administer a patient's PODs to a different patient.

All patients (emergency or elective), via relatives/carers if appropriate, should be actively encouraged by all staff to bring in patients' own drugs (PODs) from home. Medicines must not be sent back home.

Care home patients may send medicines in a ‘red bag' and this must be inspected as part of the receiving of the patient onto the ward/unit. Other healthcare Trusts (i.e. mental health) may need to send in medicines e.g. specialists drugs that are not or cannot be stocked by the MSE pharmacy department (e.g. clozapine).
PODs must be transferred with the patient to different inpatient clinical areas throughout their stay, and this includes from A&E/Assessment units to the admitting ward.
For infection control measures to be taken e.g. during a pandemic please refer to appendix
Storage of POD's

16.7.1 All room-temperature (ambient) stored medicines must be stored in the locked bedside medicine locker. Fridge items must be kept in the ward/dept. fridge. Refer to MSEPO-20205 Policy for the Safe and Secure Storage of Medicines.
16.7.2 For received POD controlled drugs or an unidentified substance (suspected illicit substance) please refer to MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs Policy.
16.7.3 When patients are moved between clinical areas and departments their own medicines must be transferred with them in a designated medicines bag. Always
ensure on transfer or discharge that the bedside medicine locker is empty, and PODs are not left in the ward CD cupboard or fridge.
Suitability of using POD's

16.8.1 Administering persons must assess the suitability of using PODs before considering using them. Ward pharmacy staff support this process, where available, by assessing PODs as part of the medicines reconciliation process.

16.8.2 Where determined suitable, in cases of infection outbreak (including COVID-19 pandemic) all POD containers should be wiped over with the Trust anti-infective cleansing wipes (e.g. clinell®) before use.
16.8.3 If unsuitable or unsure do not use the POD. Seek advice from ward pharmacy staff or obtain a new supply from pharmacy.
16.8.4 Unsuitable medicines should be separated from other drugs and, with the permission of the patient/ carer, be removed for disposal by Trust staff.
PODs must only be used if they meet the following criteria:
16.9.1 The POD has been prescribed on the patient's current Trust drug chart.
16.9.2 Label on medicine container is legible and clearly states:
Correct name of patient (this must be the same as the patient admitted);
Name, strength and formulation of drug;
Instructions for use;
Date dispensed;
Expiry date;
Name and address of supplier/issuing pharmacy.
There should be no unclear alterations to the label that do not correspond with the prescription.
16.9.3 Container itself must be:
Suitably closed bottle or intact box;
Visibly clean;
Within expiry date (dispensing label or original manufacturer's).
16.9.4 Contents of the container must be:
Clearly identifiable to cross-reference with the prescription, container and label;
Exactly matching what is on the container label;
Visibly clean;
In good condition without signs of deterioration;
Only one type of medication (no mixed medicines in same container);
Within expiry date (see below).
16.9.5 For opened medicines, revised expiry dates are:
If re-packaged into bottle (loose tablets), revised expiry date should be 3 months from date of dispensing unless specified;

If re-packaged into a plain dispensing carton (e.g. white box with tablets in a blister strip), revised expiry date should be 3 months from date of dispensing unless expiry date is clearly visible on each individual blister-strip within the carton;
Opened topical preparations may be used for 3 months from date of dispensing unless otherwise specified.
Do not use items requiring fridge or other special storage. Refer these to pharmacy for advice or resupply.
Refer also to expiry date checking section in MSEPO-20205 Policy for Safe and Secure Storage of Medicines for further information.
Re-labelling of POD's

16.10.1  Pharmacy staff may re-label suitable PODs if directions are changed during the patients stay. Labels must not be altered by anyone on the ward in the event of a changed dose; they must only be relabelled by pharmacy.
Multi-compartment dispensing systems (MDS) (Blister packs / Dossette)
16.11.1 MDS/Blister packs should not be used to obtain a dose to administer.
16.11.2 In exceptional circumstances, and only under specific pharmacist advice, a dose can be given where the medicine is critical and there is no alternative. The drug must be readily identifiable.

16.11.3 An assessment of MDS suitability for future use (i.e. discharge) as per criteria above should be undertaken. Refer also to Discharge Medication Policy (or equivalent) and MSEPO-21084 Appropriate Use of Medication Compliance Aids Policy.
Safekeeping of POD's not currently in use
16.12.1 These are medicines that may be:
not-prescribed (including alternative medicines);
temporarily stopped;
not suitable for use, but patient has not consented for removal.

16.12.2 These should be placed in a designated ‘medicines not currently in use' bag in the bedside medicine locker, which is then sealed closed. Administering staff must add patient name on the front of the bag. If the bag is too large it must be alternatively secured in a locked ward medicine cupboard. The presence of this bag should be documented on the drug chart.
16.12.3 If changes are made to the patient's prescribed medicines, the contents of the bag should be reviewed with additions/removals as appropriate. Patient consent for
removal of any items must be obtained and documented before removal and disposal.
16.12.4 If the bag is still in use at discharge, please refer to Discharge Medication Policy.
High-risk medicine administration requirements
Loading doses

17.1.1 Some drugs require a larger starting dose (a ‘loading dose') prior to a lower maintenance dose being given thereafter. Administering staff must be able to recognise what are a sensible loading and maintenance dose for digoxin, amiodarone, phenytoin and warfarin and any others commonly used drugs in their clinical area. Where unsure, they must refer to a prescriber.
Intravenous flushes:
17.2.1 Sodium Chloride 0.9% flush should be used to flush peripheral venous cannulae. Heparin flushes should not be routinely used to flush peripheral intravenous catheters.
17.2.2 Heparin flushes may be used to flush more complex devices such as central venous or arterial catheters but must only be administered against a valid prescription.
Oral VKA-anticoagulants (Warfarin, Acenocoumarol, Phenindione)
17.3.1 Administration should be at the 6pm drug round.
17.3.2 Prescribers should be alerted to dose patients for these doses well in advance of this time.

17.3.3 The administering person must ensure that the INR monitoring requested by the doctor has been undertaken at the correct time and that the INR is within an acceptable range before administering the medicine. The indication and therapeutic INR range (specific to the indication) must be specified.

17.3.4 Any deviation in monitoring or the INR reported must be immediately escalated to a doctor before administering the medicine. The advice given by the doctor must be documented in the patient's medical notes.
17.3.5 It is not appropriate to administer warfarin if you cannot be certain it has been dosed with the required information to dose safely.
Low molecular weight heparin (e.g. enoxaparin)
17.4.1 Once daily enoxaparin is usually administered at 6pm as inpatient, and this may be adjusted post-discharge depending on the situation for district nurses (i.e. 2pm).

17.4.2 Low molecular weight heparin is dosed by weight and renal function. Administering staff are expected to be able to check the dose is reasonable, within their competence. A dosing regimen is detailed in Trust guidelines on the intranet. As such a weight (in kg) must be present at the time of administration, preferably an accurate one.
17.4.3 Low molecular weight heparins should not be prescribed and administered with edoxaban, rivaroxaban, dabigatran or apixaban oral anticoagulants.
17.4.4 Warfarin, acenocoumarol or phenindione should only be given with enoxaparin until the INR is within range: this can be checked on the drug chart or with a prescriber if needed.
Insulin
17.5.1 It is a NHS England Never Event if a patient receives an insulin overdose due to inappropriate abbreviations or incorrect device used.

17.5.2 Exercise caution and always clarify handwritten doses where abbreviations of the word ‘unit' have been used (see section 12.4). Abbreviations are not acceptable and a reportable medication incident.

17.5.3 All insulin from vials must always be drawn up using a unit-graduated insulin syringe (e.g. ‘U50 / U100'). Never use any other type of syringe to measure or administer insulin (i.e. never IV syringes) because they are not equivalent and will result in incorrect and possibly dangerous doses being given.
17.5.4 Where a pre-made insulin infusion syringe exists, this must always be used in preference to preparing from vials for insulin intravenous infusions.

17.5.5 For all subcutaneous insulin devices (i.e. pre-filled pens /cartridges/ innolet®), the device must be used in accordance with manufacturer's instructions, to ensure administration occurs in accordance with its license. Consult any available Trust guidelines and request training before using any device you are unfamiliar with.
Diabetics adjusted for normal eating (DAFNE)
17.6.1 Some patients are trained to calculate the amount of carbohydrate in their meals and adjust their insulin dose accordingly.

17.6.2 Patients participating in this scheme will be endorsed as such on the inpatient chart. Therefore the dose administered must be based on the patient's calculation and not overridden by an administering practitioner. Note that this may be a different dose to that initially prescribed on the drug chart. This is acceptable in this circumstance.
17.6.3 Where the patient is physically limited, and cannot administer themselves, the nurse should administer the dose according to the patient's calculated dose.
17.6.4 The number of units administered must be endorsed on the drug chart alongside the administration signature. In Wellsky ePMA this endorsement must be done using a ‘nurse note'.

17.6.5 Administering staff should be cautious since some patients who undertake DAFNE may not be adhering to it. Any concerns identified related to a patient's ability to calculate their dose of rapid-acting insulin, for whatever reason, must be referred. The Diabetes team should be consulted urgently for advice.
Oral anti-diabetics (e.g. gliclazide)
17.7.1  These medicines should be given with meal rounds, and as such the drug round must prioritise these medicines to avoid delay.
Medical gases

17.8.1  Administration of any medical gas (oxygen, entonox etc.) must be in accordance with a valid prescription, except oxygen when initiated in an emergency. Please refer to Medical Gases Policy (or equivalent) and Oxygen Therapy Policy (or equivalent).
Potassium Chloride

17.9.1  Please refer to the Safe Handling of Medicines Policy (or equivalent). Administering Staff should be aware that readily available infusion bags containing potassium are to be used wherever possible. Any requirement of a potassium chloride ampoule should be considered exceptional in general ward environments, and will be challenged before supply by pharmacy.
Anti- Parkinson's medicines

17.10.1  These must be given at specific times of the day as detailed by the prescriber. It is likely that these may fall outside the routine drug round times. It is essential that administration is at the specific time and is not delayed. The use of reminder alerts (e.g. timer alarms) and ‘clock signs' are strongly recommended to be use by wards for this purpose.
Potassium Permanganate soaks
17.11.1 These are provided as solid permitab ‘crystals' that are dissolved in a volume of water to produce a topical soak. This is for external use only.
17.11.2 The permitab crystal must never be given to a patient in solid form. The soak must only be made up in a bucket/large container and patients advised for topical use only.

17.11.3 These must be stored in the external medicines cupboard and never the drug trolley or patient bedside medicine locker. This is because they may be confused for oral medicines. If swallowed they will cause serious patient harm.
Emollient topical products
17.12.1 There is a risk of severe and fatal burns with all emollients.

17.12.2 Emollients can transfer from the skin onto clothing, bedding, dressings, and other fabric. Once there, they can dry onto the fabric and build up over time. In the presence of a naked flame, fabric with emollient dried on is easily ignited. This is a serious risk to all patients who smoke, are around people who do or are close to naked flames (e.g. candles, open fires etc.)

17.12.3 Although emollients are not flammable in themselves or when on the skin, when dried on to fabric they act as an accelerant, increasing the speed of ignition and intensity of the fire. This accelerant effect significantly reduces the time available to act to put out a clothing or bedding fire before serious and fatal burns are sustained (MHRA, 2018).

17.12.4 Staff should advise patients accordingly and ensure any patient leaving the ward to smoke has an overcoat (or similar) to cover any clothing or dressings. Leaflets are supplied by pharmacy for all affected, newly prescribed topical products.
Oral liquid and enteral administration requirements
Cups and spoons
18.1.1 Graduated measuring cups and 5ml spoons must only be used for:
patients able to swallow liquid medication using them, and
volumes in multiples of 5ml, i.e. 10ml, 15ml, 20ml, 25ml etc.
18.1.2 Never use cups and spoons for measuring controlled drugs (refer to MSEPO-20237 Controlled Drugs Policy).
Oral syringes (for oral and enteral routes)
18.2.1 Oral/enteral syringes, designed for oral liquid medicines, must always be used in the following situations to measure or administer doses to give by oral or enteral route:
Doses that cannot be accurately measured using a medicine cup or 5ml spoon;
Volumes of medication not a multiple of 5ml;
All administration via an enteral feeding tube;
Where administration from a medicine cup or 5ml spoon is unsuitable (e.g. paediatrics and patients with special care requirements).
18.2.2 Wrong route administration of oral/ enteral medicines (i.e. given by injection in error) is part of an NHS Never Event and has been implicated in severe patient harm and fatal consequences.
18.2.3 Oral syringes are coloured purple to be visually distinct to those use for injections, so cannot be mistaken. Alternative colour oral/enteral syringes exist in restricted
areas (i.e. amber). These must be formally risk assessed with the Chief Nursing Officer responsible & accountable for their use.
18.2.4 Never use any other type of syringe for measuring or administering oral or enteral medicines (IV or other standard clear oral syringes are strictly forbidden).
18.2.5 Clinical areas giving oral liquid medicines must always stock a range of oral syringe sizes to ensure a safe, appropriate sized syringe is always available to select.

18.2.6 Use the smallest syringe possible to measure a dose because this minimises the risk of overdosing. Oral syringes also have a dead space that increases the larger the syringe (e.g. 1ml syringe can contain up to 0.3ml of dead space).

18.2.7 All oral syringes within the Trust are for single-use only. Never sterilise oral syringes. This is on the grounds of infection control within a hospital environment and the unknown effect on the integrity of the syringe and plunger.
18.2.8 Oral syringes should be disposed of in a yellow sharps bin. Follow Trust policy for waste disposal (or equivalent).
Administration via nasogastric, gastrostomy or jejunostomy feeding tube

18.3.1 Oral /enteral syringes have luer connectors designed to fit into enteral administration tubes. They are not compatible with and will not fit into IV giving sets, therefore making inadvertent administration by the IV route impossible. As such, no adapter or separate line is needed for oral/enteral syringes.

18.3.2 Small syringes (<60ml) should be used with caution as these produce high pressures and are more likely to rupture and/or collapse the tubing if excessive force is applied to the plunger. They should only be used once tube patency has been established (a 60ml purple oral syringe should be used cautiously for flushing tubes).

18.3.3 Before administration, stop the enteral feed to prevent any interaction with the medicine and the enteral feed. For adult patients Flush the tube with 30ml of water using a  ml purple syringe (which exert low pressure, minimising the risk of stomach damage). Then administer the medicine slowly and then flush the tube again afterwards with 30ml water. This prevents interaction with the feed and risk of tube blockage. The feel can then be restarted afterward. For paediatric patients always refer to paediatric departmental protocols.
18.3.4 Some medicines such as phenytoin suspension require the enteral feed to be stopped for a longer period of time to allow complete absorption of the drug. Consult pharmacy for advice.
Medicated patch administration requirements

Always check for and remove the old patch before replacing with a new one. Check all possible sites of application, especially on admission to hospital where documented site of application may not be available.

Always apply patches to clean, non-hairy sites to ensure firm adherence to the skin. Care must be taken when applying the patch not to touch the adhesive side. The patch should not be wrinkled and lay flat across the skin to ensure even and reliable absorption. The date of application may be written on the patch using a permanent felt-tip pen. However never use a ballpoint (Biro®) pen because this can damage the patch.

Avoid heating the patch as this can significantly increase absorption of the drug. Patients must be advised to avoid heat on the patch (e.g. hot water bottle, leaning against radiators, hot baths etc.).

Rotate sites of application in accordance with manufacturer guidelines. Repeated application to the same site can lead to sensitivity reactions and build-up of the drug in one area under the skin (i.e. buprenorphine weekly patches should not be applied to the same area of skin for 3-4 weeks).
On patch replacement day document (as per section 19.7):
Old patch has been removed;
Where new patch is sited (e.g. left shoulder) to enable tracking of sites.
Patches must be monitored (and this documented) daily to check the patch is still intact and undamaged. If missing this must be urgently checked not stuck to someone else or bedsheets.
Document patch monitoring as follows:
19.7.1 WellSky ePMA: Sign for the pre-built checks (co-prescribed automatically with the patch) in same way as signing for drug administration. Document patch site using the designated ‘Patch' code.
19.7.2 Paper drug charts / other ePMA systems: Use the separate paper medicated patch monitoring chart and keep with the paper drug chart.
Remove patches by carefully peeling off and fold sticky-sides together so that the adhesive surface is not exposed. Dispose of immediately in a yellow sharps bin.
Non-daily medication administration requirements (including
Methotrexate)
On sites using paper charts prescriptions for medicines to be given non-daily (i.e. alternate days, every 3 days, every 7 days etc.) must have extra endorsement on the drug chart.
All non-daily prescriptions must be presented with a clear ‘X' on days not to be given and a bold box overwritten in ink around the day to be administered.
There must be an endorsement beside the administration boxes stating ‘Day' or ‘Weekly' for weekly dosing or specific frequency for all other variants (i.e. ‘every 3 days').
e.g.
Give weekly (every Sunday)
X  X  X  X  X  X  X  X  X  X  X  X

Non-daily medicines without these endorsements must not be given until the prescription is clarified AND corrected by a prescriber. The administering person must alert the prescriber and/or pharmacy immediately.
Methotrexate Administration

20.5.1 Overdose of methotrexate is included in the NHS England Never Event list. In non- oncology use methotrexate must be prescribed and administered once a week only. If given too frequently it can result in toxicity and is potentially fatal.

20.5.2 Methotrexate must never be administered until the prescription is verified by a Pharmacist on the paper drug chart or WellSky ePMA. On paper charts the designated ‘Pharmacy Screen' box will be annotated & dated next to the prescription. On WellSky ePMA a tick is displayed next to the drug name (instead of a question mark ‘?'). This ensures an appropriate safety check for accuracy has been undertaken before it is administered.
Monitoring patients & reporting Adverse Drug Reactions (ADRs)
Monitoring for Side Effects
21.1.1 Staff are expected to be familiar with common side effects of the medicine they are administering and how and when this should be monitored.
21.1.2 The administering person must ensure they are available and are able to carry out such monitoring (or appropriately handing over). This will be in accordance with
monitoring advice stated in the product literature, any Trust guidelines or as directed by the prescriber and/or pharmacy.
Reporting Adverse Drug Reactions (ADRs)

21.2.1 Any staff detecting an adverse drug reaction must notify medical staff and/or pharmacist immediately. Adverse drug reactions must be documented in the patient health record. Where assessment of the patient suggests the medication is no longer suitable, the medical staff must be notified without delay for immediate action.
21.2.2 Treat the adverse drug reaction in line with Trust guidance, including the Anaphylaxis Treatment and Investigation Policy/guideline (or equivalent).
21.2.3 Adverse Drug Reactions (ADRs) should always be reported.
21.2.4 An incident report should be written on the Trust's incident reporting system (Datix, DCIQ) and reported nationally (i.e. as a MHRA yellow card), where appropriate.

21.2.5 Pharmacists are involved in monitoring the adverse effects of medicines. It is essential that they are kept informed of the details of suspected reactions to medicines. Staff can also contact the MSE Pharmacy Medicines Information Centre.
21.2.6 The Yellow Card reporting scheme is a national system essential in the detection of previously unrecognised adverse drug reactions with medicines use.
21.2.7 Always report, using the yellow card, for:

All suspected adverse reactions to recently introduced medicines should be reported. These products are marked with a triangle on the British National Formulary and sometimes on the medicine packaging;
For all other medicines serious or unusual reactions which may be due to the treatment shall be reported.
21.2.8 The yellow card is accessible:
Online via https://yellowcard.mhra.gov.uk/
Via Smartphone app – Yellow card Scheme;
Paper versions are available in the paper version of BNF (where available) which can be sent to the site pharmacy department.
Critical medicines
These are essential medicines where timeliness of administration is crucial and must not be omitted.

For some critical medicines or conditions, such as patients with sepsis or those with pulmonary embolisms, delays or omissions can cause serious harm or death. Patients going into hospital with chronic conditions are particularly at risk from loss
of symptom control and associated negative health effects resulting from this (NPSA, 2010).
The critical medicines list is published on the intranet and should be referred to by all administering persons in the course of the medicines administration process.
Where the drug is not readily available it must be obtained as quickly as possible. Please refer to actions when drug is not available (appendix 1).
Administering staff must not allow a critical medicine to completely run out before requesting further supplies as this can delay treatment.
Omissions (non-administration) and delayed administration

Non-administration of medicines can be as dangerous to patient safety as administration of incorrect medicines. Therefore omitting a medicine must only ever be considered as a last resort, and never routine for convenience.

When a medicine cannot be administered, a reason must be documented on the drug chart, at the time of the non-administration decision or as soon as possible thereafter. The decision not to administer (omit) may occur later on (i.e. because actions taken to try to administer later in the shift have been unsuccessful).

Non-administered reasons (‘codes') exist for this purpose, and these must only be used in accordance with this policy. Additional explanations of reasons for omission are to be documented as a ‘note' within Wellsky ePMA (where exists) and patient's health record.

23.3.1 In Wellsky ePMA these can be selected from a drop down list beside the medicine. Caution: If a non-administered code is entered in Wellsky ePMA it cannot be undone and the medication is no longer available to administer.
23.3.2 On paper drug charts the codes are printed at the top of the chart. Write the relevant code in the appropriate box on the administration grid next to the affected medicine.
STAT doses

23.4.1  Medication must never be omitted if unavailable. In Wellsky ePMA the chart must be left blank and drug obtained without delay. The dose may then be given when available. If a non-administered code is entered in Wellsky ePMA it cannot be undone and the medication is no longer available to administer.
Regularly-prescribed doses

23.5.1  The box should never be left blank by the end of the shift. It is mandatory in Wellsky ePMA for all doses for the preceding 24hour be accounted for (signed for or non- administered) before allowing any doses to be administered the following day.
Escalation process for non-administered medication
23.6.1 Specific actions are required for each non-administered (omission) code entered on a drug chart. It is unacceptable to fill in the administration box as an omission and take no further action.
23.6.2 The use of each non-administered reason must be followed up by appropriate actions to safety-net the patient from potential harm from the omission.

23.6.3 It is essential that all actions are followed in order to prevent delays and omissions of treatment where alternative arrangements are possible. Delays and lack of action can and has resulted in patient harm.
23.6.4 Please refer to appendix 1 for details of actions to take for each non-administered (omission) code.
Drug not available
23.7.1 Stating the drug is not available must be a last resort and never routine practice.

23.7.2 All reasonable attempts must be made to ensure the drug is administered and not delayed. Professional judgement should be applied to ensure critical medicines are prioritised and obtained immediately (see appendix 1).

23.7.3 It is expected that drugs required from pharmacy are requested, and obtained, as early as possible. The administering staff are responsible for informing pharmacy of requests (and their level of urgency – i.e. time needed), and for collecting them in a timely manner.
Patient Refusal / Declining of medicines

23.8.1 There are important questions to ask and explore if a patient declines treatment. Does patient understand risks of refusal? Do they have the capacity to make this decision? Have they been provided with the right information to make this decision?
23.8.2 Please refer also to appendix 1 and section 25.
23.8.3 It is essential that documentation of refusal and reasons is clear, complete and has been escalated to the prescriber without delay.
Nil-by-Mouth and peri-operative patient requirements

Patients outside the perioperative period are sometimes classified as ‘Nil-by-Mouth' (NBM). It should not be assumed that although the patient cannot consume food or oral fluids that medication also be omitted.

For critical medicines (e.g. analgesia, anti- Parkinson's, anti-epileptics) it is essential that treatment is considered for continuation or reviewed so an alternative can be given such as another route (e.g. by injection).
The degree to which the patient is nil by mouth can be defined as follows:
