Only where a patient is classified as Strictly NBM should the NBM omission code be entered on the drug chart for oral medicines. Medicines for other routes should be administered as prescribed.
The NBM status should be reviewed regularly to ensure it remains appropriate as the patient's status changes.
Perioperative Administration

24.7.1  Administration of medicines may need to be altered in the period before and after surgery. All routine medications should be given to pre-operative fasted patients. Exceptions to this will be explicitly stated in the patient's medical notes as part of their pre-operative plan.
Covert administration

Covert administration is a defined process whereby a formal decision has been made between healthcare professionals and carers, for medicines to be administered in a disguised format without the knowledge or consent of the patient who lacks mental capacity (RPS/RCN, 2019).
Where deemed necessary, covert administration of medicines takes place within the context of existing legal and best practice frameworks.
All staff involved in the practice of administering medicines covertly must be fully aware of the aims, intent and implications of such treatment.

Covert administration can refer to medication given to treat either mental or physical health problems. For patients / clients detained under the Mental Health Act, the principles of consent continue to apply to any medications for the conditions not related to the mental health disorder for which they have been detained.
When can you administer covertly?
25.5.1  Medicines must be administered covertly only to people who:
actively refuse their medication and;
are considered to lack mental capacity, at that time, and;

their treatment with medication is considered essential to save the person's life, to prevent deterioration or ensure improvement in the person's mental or physical health, or for the safety of others, and;
have their medicines administered strictly in accordance with an agreed, documented management care plan.
Outside of the above requirements, covert administration is considered unnecessary, inappropriate and unlawful.
25.6.1 Medication must never be disguised for the convenience of the healthcare team.
25.6.2 Disguising medication in the absence of informed consent may be regarded as deception.

25.6.3 Staff must be aware that non-compliance with this policy can be considered in breach of their professional / job role responsibilities. They may be subject to disciplinary action by not only the organisation but also their professional regulatory body (i.e. NMC).
Capacity & consent principles
Every adult must be presumed to have the mental capacity to consent or refuse treatment, including medication, unless he or she:
Is unable to take in and retain the information provided by the treating staff;
Is unable to understand that information;
Is unable to weigh up the information as part of the decision making process (i.e. unable to under understand the consequences of their refusal, at that time);
Is unable to communicate back the decision to the treating staff.
25.8.1  With respect to medicines the minimum information a patient and/or carer should receive in order to make a decision are:
What is the medicine for;
How is it used (including demonstration if appropriate);
What are the side effects.
The pharmacy team can help with all of these questions.
Take into consideration the patient's known wishes, values, religious belief and views. Some issues such as what the medicine is made from may be managed through discussion with the pharmacist.

Disguising medication in order to save life, prevent deterioration, or ensure an improvement in the person's physical or mental health, cannot be taken in isolation from the recognition of the rights of the person to give consent.
The multidisciplinary team must first make every effort to obtain the patient's consent; and to administer medicines openly; and must continue such efforts throughout admission.
Assessing Capacity
25.12.1 Mental capacity must be formally assessed and documented in accordance with this policy and MSEPO-21103 Mental Capacity Act policy; where the assessment paperwork is provided.

25.12.2 MSEPO-21103 takes into account considerations required under the Mental Capacity Act 2005 (and related legislation). It details how to approach situations where a patient's best interests need to be considered.
25.12.3 The assessment of capacity must be overseen by the doctor caring for the patient, with other members of the multidisciplinary team participating in the decision making process.

25.12.4 With regards to children and young people under the age of 16 years, it is the responsibility of the Clinician to establish the patient's Fraser competence to consent. However in law, the parent or guardian with parental responsibility retain the right to consent.
25.12.5 The Safeguarding Team are available to provide advice and support on all of the above issues.
Decision to administer covertly
25.13.1 No decision to administer covertly can be made without lack of capacity assessed, agreed and appropriately documented.

25.13.2 The decision to administer covertly is one that has been informed and agreed by the multidisciplinary team, including the doctor caring for the patient, and not by a single healthcare professional. It must also include a broad and open discussion between the clinical team and the patient's carers or advocates before the judgment is taken; and be evidenced that covert administration is in the patient's best interest.
25.13.3 The decision to administer medication covertly should be considered as a contingency measure in an emergency rather than as regular practice.
25.13.4 A further distinction should be made for patients:
whom no disguising is necessary because they are unaware they are receiving medication;
who would be aware, if they were not deceived into thinking otherwise.
This is important for establishing what methods of medicines administration may be appropriate.
25.13.5 Where covert administration is deemed appropriate, a clear, documented care plan must be drawn up and present within the patients' health record. It must clearly state:
The decision and action taken, including the names of all parties concerned;
How the decision has been reached;
Which medicines are to be administered covertly;
How the medicines will be administered (following assessment by a pharmacist).
Review of decision and plan

25.14.1 The care plan must be reviewed at appropriate intervals. In particular this must take into account whether the patient continues to lack capacity and whether use of covert medication remains the most appropriate way of providing treatment.
25.14.2 Regular attempts should be made to encourage the patient to take medication voluntarily.
25.14.3 Other options may include changing the formulation of the medicine or treatment regimen (e.g. timings, a different drug for same indication etc.).
Methods of medicines administration

25.15.1 The method of covert administration of medicines for a specific patient must be discussed and agreed with a pharmacist. They will provide advice on how to covertly administer medicines safely and whether the medication can be crushed, capsules opened etc. or mixed with food or drink (see section below).
25.15.2 Advice for disguising the medication will be documented by pharmacy on the drug chart and relevant part of the patient health record, where possible.
25.15.3 Crushing, opening of capsules or mixing with foodstuffs must never occur without prior consultation with a pharmacist.
Discharge from hospital

The decision to administer medicines covertly must be communicated to the home/carer. It is then their decision to follow local policies for continued covert administration of medicine. This should be documented on the discharge summary.
Liaise with safeguarding as appropriate.
Crushing tablets / opening capsules / mixing with food

Crushing and opening capsules is an unlicensed activity and may affect the absorption of the drug. This can lead to treatment failure and/or toxicity. Mixing of such medication with food may also be unlicensed and affect drug performance.
If a patient is unable to swallow tablets or capsules, advice must be sought from pharmacy.

Never crush or open capsules without consultation with a pharmacy professional. Where crushing is recommended the directions must be followed exactly. For some preparations it may be acceptable to open a capsule but not crush its contents, for example.

Never mix medication with foods and supplements without seeking advice from pharmacy. Some drugs, for example, will bind to food and not be absorbed. The routine practice of mixing with yogurts etc. is not permitted without confirmation from pharmacy that this is safe to do.

Advice given by a registered pharmacist or pharmacy technician will be documented as a note within the ePMA system in use or be handwritten onto the drug chart and signed. This endorsement indicates this method of administration is approved for the administering person to give. Pharmacy staff will only advise on actions where the integrity of the medication being administered is not significantly impaired by the processes employed.
Always use a tablet crusher device to crush approved medicines. Crushers are available from pharmacy, on request.
Never use any other piece of equipment for crushing. To prevent cross contamination never use a mortar and pestle.

When a medication is administered in foodstuff, it is the responsibility of the administering person to ensure that the medication has been taken in full. If this is observed, and full administration of the dose was not possible this must be documented and the doctor caring for the patient informed.
Outpatient clinics
All medicines must be administered only against valid, legal prescriptions or directions to administer, as per this policy.

Medicines to be administered in the clinic may be prescribed in the patients notes by the prescribing doctor. This includes emergency drugs (e.g. insulin), and topical preparations (e.g. for dressing changes).
The practitioner administering the medicine should sign and date the notes to indicate the medicine has been administered.
Record the administration on the prescription/in the notes including dose and time given. If a doctor is administering without a prescription then ensure all information is documented in the notes.

Selection of medication for administration in an outpatient environment including preparation of trolleys or trays for clinics may only be performed by an appropriately trained registered professional. These staff will be authorised by the divisional most senior divisional nurse, midwife or AHP, who will ensure training is in place and has been completed.
Catheter laboratory (Diagnostic Imaging Department)
Due to the number of drugs that may or may not be used during procedures, to prescribe in advance is not only time consuming, but omissions of necessary drugs may still occur.
This section enables registered nurses and registered radiographers to administer drugs on the verbal request of the operating doctor.
This does not include any situations where an approved patient group direction (PGD) exists or the doctor (e.g. radiologist) has issued a patient specific direction (PSD). PSD examples include:
radiologists request for contrast whilst screening referrals;
doctors requesting bowel prep via electronic request system.

Registered nurses must have successfully completed the Trust Nuclear Medicine programme for administration of intravenous medication. Registered radiographers must have successfully completed the Diagnostic Imaging Department competency assessment overseen and signed off by senior Radiographic staff within the department.

Radiographers must have undertaken training related to the drugs being administered (or be directly supervised whilst undergoing training). This includes understanding what side-effects may occur and ensuring appropriate monitoring of the patient occurs.

The registered nurse / radiographer must demonstrate, and be signed off, that they are competent in the safe use and observation of any medical equipment/devices they need to use; including adherence to nuclear medicine local protocols for radiation safety.

The nurse or radiographer will prepare the drug on the verbal request of the operating doctor. The drug requested will be repeated back to the doctor for confirmation prior to administration. This will follow the principles within MSEPO- 21085 Verbal Prescribing Orders Policy and Procedures.
The drug will be checked (correct name, dose and within expiry date), with a registered staff member (nurse, doctor or radiographer).

The drug, dose, route of administration, time of administration and person administering drug will be recorded in the relevant procedure record which will be signed by a doctor at the conclusion of the procedure.
Any infusions left running when patients leave the department must also be recorded on a Trust drug chart and handed over to the nurse-in-charge of the receiving area.
Nuclear medicine department

Due to the radioactive nature of the drugs used for nuclear medicine, there are radiation safety regulations to consider in addition to medicines regulations. Therefore administration procedures differ slightly from the standard process.
Prescription / direction to administer
29.2.1 Medicines for nuclear medicine can be administered and supplied against a nuclear medicine referral authorised in accordance with an ARSAC certificate holder's guidelines.
29.2.2 Nuclear medicine referrals will not always specify patient weight and patient allergies. Nuclear medicine staff must therefore
measure patient weight when needed for dose calculation;
always question patients about possible allergies.
Second-checking
29.3.1 For nuclear medicine procedures, suitably experienced (assessed as competent) nuclear medicine technologists, radiographers and physicists may carry out second- checking.
29.3.2 Second-checking of drug selection, drawing-up and measurement is required in the following circumstances:
All therapeutic-level radiopharmaceuticals, including both IV and non-IV;
All radiopharmaceuticals for paediatrics.
29.3.3 Second-checking of diagnostic-level radiopharmaceuticals for adult patients is not routinely needed due to the low-risk nature of this work
29.3.4 Second-checking is performed at the drawing-up stage rather than at the administration stage, in order to minimise radiation dose to staff.
Batch Drawing-Up and Drug Handover
29.4.1 For radiation safety reasons drawing up of radioactive drugs is normally performed in a non-patient area and so there is inevitably some delay between drawing-up and patient administration.

29.4.2 In some circumstances in nuclear medicine, multiple patient doses may be drawn up and transferred to the patient area in batches. Such batch drawing-up may only be performed if the drugs can be well-segregated, clearly-labelled and properly- shielded.
29.4.3 Examples of such batch transfers would include:
batches of MIBI doses being transferred to the heart and chest clinic for myocardial stress sessions;
batches of nanocolloid being transferred to theatres for intra-operative sentinel lymph node studies.

29.4.4 Drawing-up and measurement of radioactive medicine requires different skills to those required for administration so there can be occasions when the member of staff administering the radiopharmaceutical has not witnessed the drawing-up stage. Such handover of radiopharmaceuticals may only be performed if the drugs can be well-segregated, clearly-labelled and properly-shielded.
29.4.5 Examples of such transfers would include:
Batches of MIBI doses being transferred to the heart and chest clinic for cardiac nurses to inject.
Batches of nanocolloid being transferred to theatres for the surgeon to inject.
For nuclear medicine procedures, records of administered drugs are documented on the Trust's computerised Radiology Information System.
Renographer & Dialysis Assistant administration of medicines
Renographers and Dialysis Assistants must adhere to the content and principles of this policy.
Renographers

30.2.1 Renographers are non-registered healthcare practitioners and working under the supervision of specialist registered renal dialysis nurses. They are principally employed to support haemodialysis. As they are non-registered practitioners, named registered nurses are accountable for the actions of renographers during the administration of any medicines.

30.2.2 All renographers undergo, and are signed off, using a competency based Trust training programme delivered by the renal unit dialysis registered nursing staff. In line with registered nurses, they must demonstrate on-going competency and undertake further training / updates as required following annual appraisal (as a minimum).

30.2.3 All Renographers are responsible for the activities detailed below, regardless of the job band in which they sit. The individual is responsible for only undertaking tasks in which they are permitted in accordance with Renal Unit protocols and this policy.
Dialysis Assistants working in Renal Unit

30.3.1 Dialysis Assistants assist in the daily running of the Renal Unit, by preparing dialysis therapy and general housekeeping of the Renal Unit. They are employed to support the Renal Unit and work under the management of the registered nurses.

30.3.2 All Dialysis Assistants undergo, and are signed off, using a competency-based Trust training programme delivered by the renal unit dialysis registered nursing staff. In line with registered nurses, they must demonstrate on-going competency
and undertake further training / updates as required following annual appraisal (as a minimum).
30.3.3 Dialysis Assistants are responsible for assembly of the Dialysis line with Sodium Chloride 0.9% 500ml bag and Dialysate only against a valid dialysis protocol.
All drugs prepared for renographers to administer must have a second independent check by a registered nurse prior to administration.
Renographers may only administer the following drugs within the course of their practice, and sign the pre-printed prescription chart:
Lidocaine 1%;
Heparin Sodium (all available strengths);
Sodium Chloride 0.9%;
Sodium Bicarbonate;
Dialysate.

The drugs required to be administered will be specified on the dialysis profile (protocol) following the initial dialysis prescription by a consultant nephrologist. Any changes to this e.g. heparin rates, which fall outside of the documented doses, must be amended by a prescriber prior to administration.

Details of the drugs administered, the signature for the registered nursing check & subsequent administration must be recorded on the reverse of the patient's dialysis profile sheet. This information is transferred electronically onto the department ‘Proton' computer system the same day. Original paper copies are retained on the unit for 1 month before being destroyed.
Operating Theatres: preparation of medicines in anaesthesia

It is considered “best practice” that the preparation of medicines is carried out by the administrating clinician; however, in the operating theatre this practice is not always considered to be in the best interest of the patient where it is necessary to have emergency medicines already drawn up for the rapid response in a given situation.
The preparation of emergency medicines can be carried out by an ODP or registered nurse, who has received appropriate additional qualification in anaesthetics from an institute of higher education.
An ODP acting as anaesthetic assistant may prepare medicines (draw up) in advance for individual patients at an anaesthetist's request.

The ODP acting as anaesthetic assistant must have knowledge and understanding of the drug being administered, the route, dosage and strength of the drug, its potential action and contraindications. This activity must NOT be undertaken by any
theatre practitioner who does not feel confident or competent to do so and this must be made known to the medical practitioner.

A drug on verbal request by a medical practitioner can be administered by a theatre practitioner under direct supervision. All verbal requests must be followed up by records and appropriate documentation.
In accordance with the law any person can administer a drug to a patient in accordance with the directions of a doctor or an authorised prescriber.
Process for administration
Drugs must be drawn up in an aseptic manner in accordance with the Trust aseptic technique policy (or equivalent);
Draw up only one medicine at a time;
Label the syringe immediately after the medicine has been drawn up (do not pre- label syringes);
Do not entertain any interruptions during this task;
A second qualified member of staff must check both the medicine and flushing solution. The checker can be a doctor, a registered nurse or registered ODP;
Double check the ampoules and syringe labels when handing over to ensure the correct medicine and diluent have been used and that the drug is within expiry date;

All ampoules and syringes must be kept in a receiver container until they have been recorded prior to disposal of by the person who administered the drug or the qualified practitioner delegated to do so;
Previous patient's drugs must be discarded prior to admitting next patient into the anaesthetic room.
31.7.1  It is the responsibility of the anaesthetist to delegate preparation of medicines to an assistant, although the overall responsibility remains with the anaesthetist:
The drug (s) must be checked by the medical practitioner

The drug, dose and expiry date must be checked. Ideally undertaken prior to administration; however this may not be possible during an emergency situation. Under these circumstances all ampoules and syringes must be kept in a receiver until they have been recorded prior to disposal of by the person who administered the drug or the theatre practitioner delegated to do so.
In a team situation (other than an emergency) tasks should be reallocated so as not to place any practitioner or patient at risk.
Training requirements
Medicines administration competency training and sign off is delivered vocationally in the clinical setting. Supervision is overseen by the senior nurse/midwife for that clinical area.
All administering staff must have valid medication competencies completed. These form part of the induction training to the role.
Further competencies are required for specialist medicines (including specialist routes) as detailed in their respective policies.

Specialist clinical areas may also have their own competency assessments, and these may be for defined staff groups, which must be completed and signed off before the person is authorised to administer those medicines.

Competencies are not usually required to be repeated unless this is mandated by the professional/regulatory body. However a need to revisit these may be identified through personal reflection and/or incident review. It is usually only relevant to repeat some medication competencies, related to the specific issue/s identified, rather than full re-training; unless evidence defines otherwise.

Appendix 2: Infection control measures for patients own medicines
These infection control measures must be undertaken in clinical areas treating patients affected by a pandemic (e.g. COVID-19):
All patients own drugs (PODS) including controlled drugs MUST be wiped down with Clinell wipes (or equivalent). This includes all boxes and blisters.

Pharmacy staff reviewing pods of suspected/confirmed Covid-19 positive patients should not be standard practice, however if essential they must wash their hands and clinell (or equivalent) wipe down any equipment touched during the process (e.g. laptops), avoid touching paper or pens.
All bedside lockers MUST be cleaned between patients in line with the current Trust guidance.
Fridge items must be kept separate from stock supplies in a designated basket or other suitable container.

If POD's are no longer required, medicines (except CD's) MUST not be returned to pharmacy. POD medicines for disposal MUST be sealed and discarded at ward/dept. level as per infectious waste (i.e. in the infectious waste bins on the ward/dept.)

If any bedside locker medications have changed, (new dose etc.) and instructions on the label are no longer appropriate, DO NOT send the item to pharmacy to be relabelled. The item MUST be obtained on the ward - your pharmacy team will make arrangements to have it re-labelled, or more likely, re-supply it. If a supply is made, the POD must be disposed of.
